entry.title: From Dedekind's Nachlass (Cod. Ms. Dedekind III 1), screenshotted from https://www.youtube.com/live/XSaW_flm27A?feature=shared at time 7:10, talk by @estruppi That boxed phrase top right: "Am 10 ?Juni 1887 b?????" Can anyone make out the last word? I'm guessing 'Juni' by comparing the 'un' in 'Abbildung' and in 'und' as indicated. Elsewhere on the manuscript is written a "10 Juli 1887", but that's in what Emmylou has identified as a later addition.
entry.summary: From Dedekind's Nachlass (Cod. Can anyone make out the last word? I'm guessing 'Juni' by comparing the 'un' in 'Abbildung' and in 'und' as indicated. Elsewhere on the manuscript is written a "10 Juli 1887", but that's in what Emmylou has identified as a later addition. - theHigherGeometer (@highergeometer) July 3, 2024

entry.title: Congratulations to Noga Alon https://zbmath.org/authors/alon.noga for being awarded the 2024 Wolf Prize in Mathematics! He is known for his work in combinatorics and computer science. His paper "Combinatorial Nullstellensatz" was reviewed in https://zbmath.org/0920.05026.
entry.summary: Congratulations to Noga Alon https://zbmath.org/authors/alon.noga for being awarded the 2024 Wolf Prize in Mathematics! He is known for his work in combinatorics and computer science. His paper "Combinatorial Nullstellensatz" was reviewed in https://zbmath.org/0920.05026. - zbMATH Open (@zbMATH) July 3, 2024

entry.title: Congratulations to Adi Shamir https://zbmath.org/authors/shamir.adi for being awarded the 2024 #WolfPrize in Mathematics! He is known for his work in cryptography. 'A method for obtaining digital signatures and public-key cryptosystems' https://zbmath.org/0368.94005 (with R. L. Rivest and L. Adleman) contains his seminal work on the RSA cryptosystem.
entry.summary: Congratulations to Adi Shamir https://zbmath.org/authors/shamir.adi for being awarded the 2024 #WolfPrize in Mathematics! He is known for his work in cryptography. 'A method for obtaining digital signatures and public-key cryptosystems' https://zbmath.org/0368.94005 (with R. L. Rivest and L. Adleman) contains his seminal work on the RSA cryptosystem. - zbMATH Open (@zbMATH) July 3, 2024

entry.title: Preliminary results for the first #AIMO progress prize is up: https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/ai-mathematical-olympiad-prize/leaderboard Provisionally at least, it appears that the winning program managed to correctly answer 29/50 of the private test questions, which is somewhat higher than expected.
entry.summary: Preliminary results for the first #AIMO progress prize is up: https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/ai-mathematical-olympiad-prize/leaderboard Provisionally at least, it appears that the winning program managed to correctly answer 29/50 of the private test questions, which is somewhat higher than expected. - Terence Tao (@tao) July 3, 2024

entry.title: My eighth Math Research Livestream is now available on YouTube: https://youtu.be/aWNn_5ob448 This time, I took another look at my expository article explaining free algebras and presentations by way of division by zero. My goal was to put a new, more mathematically mature spin on my old construction from way back when, and I made some interesting progress. #math #livestream #Twitch #algebra #UniversalAlgebra #AbstractAlgebra #CategoryTheory

entry.title: BB(5) = 47,176,870 Possibly the last busy beaver number we'll ever know definitively: https://discuss.bbchallenge.org/t/july-2nd-2024-we-have-proved-bb-5-47-176-870/237 The quanta article linked at the end provides a very nice overview of the history of the humans and computers involved in the story: https://www.quantamagazine.org/amateur-mathematicians-find-fifth-busy-beaver-turing-machine-20240702/ Scott Aaronson's blog post provides some technical details and a variety of other reference links: https://scottaaronson.blog/?p=8088 Apart from the crazy technical aspects, what I find most exciting and interesting is how some (many?) of those involved are "amateur mathematicians", in it because they love mathematics and found this problem challenging. #math #TCS #BusyBeaver
entry.summary: BB(5) = 47,176,870 Possibly the last busy beaver number we'll ever know definitively: https://discuss.bbchallenge.org/t/july-2nd-2024-we-have-proved-bb-5-47-176-870/237 The quanta article linked at the end provides a very nice overview of the history of the humans and computers involved in the story: https://www.quantamagazine.org/amateur-mathematicians-find-fifth-busy-beaver-turing-machine-20240702/ Scott Aaronson's blog post provides some technical details and a variety of other reference links: https://scottaaronson.blog/?p=8088 Apart from the crazy technical aspects, what I find most exciting and interesting is how some (many?) of those involved are "amateur mathematicians", in it because they love mathematics and found this problem challenging. #math #TCS #BusyBeaver - Akshar Varma (@aksharvarma) July 2, 2024

entry.title: Spending part of my staycation watching some old movies. Spotted yet another paper sheet used to illustrate folded space time in a movie. Deja Vu (2006). I have a strange desire to collect these scenes. While I'm here, two other things worthy of note: (1) it has best use of a sci-fi idea to motivate a car chase (2) it has the absolute stupidest thing ever in a movie. It's the laser pointer scene in the trailer so just watch it. Update: Maybe it's not in all versions of the trailer so I have to describe it. Denzel Washington points a laser pointer at a display and it comes out the other end ie. in view of the people under surveillance in the display. No, it's not the space time portal. It's one of many bordered windows tiled on a large screen.
entry.summary: Spending part of my staycation watching some old movies. Spotted yet another paper sheet used to illustrate folded space time in a movie. Deja Vu (2006). It's one of many bordered windows tiled on a large screen. - Dan Piponi (@dpiponi) July 2, 2024

entry.title: Replied to: I enjoyed the Art of Noise exhibition at SFMOMA. A fun exhibit was the "choir" of 8 synthetic voices (from teenage engineering), each from a speaker in a cute separate wooden "character" enclosure.
entry.summary: But it made me sad to see an iPod nano 7G (2012) on display. Proof that the myth of the golden age has some validity. Mine's still limping along but it'll be hard to replace when it eventually gives up the ghost. - Dan Piponi (@dpiponi) July 1, 2024

entry.title: The illusion of explanatory depth is a phenomenon in psychology whereby humans are biased towards believing they understand a phenomenon better than they do because of some sense of immediacy or familiarity with it. Some classic studies on this show humans over-estimate our ability to understand how toilets, zippers and bows and arrows function at a basic level. I think about this as a structuring phenomena of almost all folk theories of social science or politics. People are thoroughly convinced, as this week has shown, that they understand things like the causes, symptoms and cures to the dangerous rise of far right, they think they understand how to better run a political campaign, and they think their preferred policies, if given the chance, would easily attract voters. What voters want or find appealing is straying into the territory of Hayek's information problem, but most of these discussions seem wi…
entry.summary: The illusion of explanatory depth is a phenomenon in psychology whereby humans are biased towards believing they understand a phenomenon better than they do because of some sense of immediacy or familiarity with it. Some classic studies on this show humans over-estimate our ability to understand how toilets, zippers and bows and arrows function at a basic level. I think about this as a structuring phenomena of almost all folk theories of social science or politics. People are thoroughly convinced, as this week has shown, that they understand things like the causes, symptoms and cures to the dangerous rise of far right, they think they understand how to better run a political campaign, and they think their preferred policies, if given the chance, would easily attract voters. What voters want or find appealing is straying into the territory of Hayek's information problem, but most of these discussions seem wildly over-optimistic and utopian regardless. The left in western democracies (if such a concept is meaningful) should spend far more time with our long list of failures, more time asking why we lose. I am adamantly in favour of a world of red plenty, but there is no path to it without such strategic thought. - Boarders (@boarders) June 30, 2024

entry.title: We're concluding our foray into the strangeness of arithmetization with an episode on Presburger Arithmetic: https://podcasters.spotify.com/pod/show/cody-roux/episodes/Presburger-Arithmetic-e2lgh2j (rss: https://anchor.fm/s/db787130/podcast/rss) Basically you can just *squeeak* by the incompletness theorems, but there's no free lunch: Presburger Arithmetic is decidable, but just barely: no decision procedure in less than \( 2^{2^{n}}\) (ish) steps!
entry.summary: We're concluding our foray into the strangeness of arithmetization with an episode on Presburger Arithmetic: https://podcasters.spotify.com/pod/show/cody-roux/episodes/Presburger-Arithmetic-e2lgh2j (rss: https://anchor.fm/s/db787130/podcast/rss) Basically you can just *squeeak* by the incompletness theorems, but there's no free lunch: Presburger Arithmetic is decidable, but just barely: no decision procedure in less than \( 2^{2^{n}}\) (ish) steps! - Cody (@codyroux) June 30, 2024
